title: Identification of spermatogenesis-associated changes in DNA methylation induced by maternal exposure to chemicals in male germ cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Isolation of germ cells from fetal testis
Timing: 2–3 h. Time may vary depending on the number of embryos obtained
This step describes the method for isolating fetal male germ cells.
Isolation of embryonic testis.
Sacrifice pregnant female mice on appropriate embryonic day.
Note: Although GFP in the Oct4-GFP transgenic embryos is specifically detectable in primordial germ cells from embryonic day (E) 7.5 onwards (Yoshimizu et al., 19992[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]), this protocol is designed for germ cell isolation from later fetuses (E15.5-E19.5).
Remove embryos from pregnant females using 8.5-cm dissecting scissors and place in DMEM containing 10% FBS and 1% penicillin/streptomycin in a 10-cm dish placed on ice.
After confirming that the fetuses have stopped moving, transfer them to a new 10-cm dish.
Remove the testes using forceps under a stereomicroscope (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2245-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Isolation of fetal germ cells at the stage of E19.5
(A) Isolated fetal mouse testis. Bar = 1 mm.
(B) Removal of the epididymis from a testis. Bars = 1 mm.
(C) Collected testes after removal of liquid.
(D) Cell suspension of testes before and after pipetting.
(E) Cell filtering set-up using 40-μm cell-strainer and 50-mL tube.
(F) Gating the main population of fetal testicular cells (R1) at the stage of E19.5.
(G) Separation of germ cells (R3) and testicular somatic cells (R2) with GFP fluorescence intensity.
Transfer the testes into a 6-cm dish with DMEM containing 10% FBS and 1% penicillin/streptomycin using a 1-mL micropipette.
Note: Cut the end of the micropipette tip using scissors to allow the testes to pass through.
Note: It can be kept for 20–30 min on ice, but further storage is not recommended at this stage.
Remove the epididymis using a curved surgical needle attached to a shaft (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Preparation of single-cell suspension.

Transfer the testes to a 15-mL centrifuge tube using a 1-mL micropipette.
Note: Up to 20 testes from the same exposure group can be placed in a 15-mL tube.
Remove as much of the medium as possible.
Add 1 mL of 1× Trypsin/EDTA and mix by repeated pipetting.
Remove the 1× Trypsin/EDTA as much liquid as possible using an aspirator after the testes have settled to the bottom of the tube.
Critical: Remove as much of the liquid as possible, because residual FBS in the medium will interfere with the trypsin reaction (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Add 1 mL of 1× Trypsin/EDTA and leave in a water bath at 37°C for 15 min with tapping in every 5 min.
Note: During this time, set a centrifuge to cool to 4°C. Also, fill a 1.5-mL tube with 1.5 mL of FBS and place the tube on ice to coat the tube with FBS. This 1.5-mL tube is used to collect cells using a cell sorter.
Pipet 20–30 times using a 1-mL micropipette until no cell aggregates are visible (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Critical: The presence of cell aggregates will result in decreased recovery of purified germ cells. If cell aggregates remain, repeat pipetting until aggregates disappear. Fragments of the membrane surrounding the testis may remain, but it is not a problem.
Add 4 mL of DMEM containing 10% FBS and mix by pipetting.
Set a 40-μm cell strainer upon a 50-mL tube (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E) and filter the cell suspension.
Count the cells once using a cell counting tool such as hemocytometer.
Centrifuge the 50-mL tube at 190 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and suspend the pellet in DMEM containing 2% FBS at 1× 106–107/mL of all the tissue cells.
Purification of germ cells.

Transfer the cell suspension into 5-mL tube and place the tube on ice.
Remove the FBS from the 1.5-mL tube prepared in step 2 and add 0.5 mL of DMEM containing 10% FBS. Use this tube for collecting sorted cells.
To purify germ cells using a cell sorter, the main cell population is gated on a scatter plot by forward scatter (FSC-A) and side scatter (SSC-A) to eliminate contaminated small materials including cell debris (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F, R1 gate) (https://www.bio-rad-antibodies.com/flow-cytometry-gates-regions.html?JSESSIONID_STERLING=3919B18883BCAC4B3C9CA7316CD6A8BC.ecommerce1&evCntryLang=JP-ja&cntry=JP&thirdPartyCookieEnabled=truehttps://expert.cheekyscientist.com/gating-strategies-get-your-flow-cytometry-data-published/[href=https://www.bio-rad-antibodies.com/flow-cytometry-gates-regions.html?JSESSIONID_STERLING=3919B18883BCAC4B3C9CA7316CD6A8BC.ecommerce1&evCntryLang=JP-ja&cntry=JP&thirdPartyCookieEnabled=true]).
GFP-positive germ cells are then gated on a histogram of GFP fluorescence of the cells in the R1 gate (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]G). The less-intense peak at the higher GFP fluorescence (R3) and more-intense peak at the lower GFP fluorescence (R2) represent GFP-positive germ cells and GFP-negative testicular somatic cells, respectively.
Alternatives: We used a Bio-Rad S3e Cell Sorter system. Other cytometers are likely suitable for this application once the proper filter/laser settings for detecting GFP have been implemented.
Note: The number of sorted testicular germ cells varies depending on the embryonic day of the fetus. In our experiments, 1,000–3,000 cells per embryo at E19.5 can be recovered.
After cell sorting, centrifuge the sorted cells in the 1.5-mL tube at 190 × g for 20 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and store the pellet at −80°C until DNA isolation.
Isolation of germ cells from adult testis
Timing: 6–7 h
This step describes the method for isolating adult male germ cells in specific stages. This protocol refers to the previous papers.14[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14],15[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]
Isolation of testes from adult mice.
Sacrifice adult male mice and remove the testes using 8.5-cm dissecting scissors (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A) and place in DMEM containing 10% FBS and 1% penicillin/streptomycin in a 10-cm dish.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2245-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Isolation of adult-stage spermatogenic germ cells

(A) Identification of testis by pulling off the epididymal adipose tissue.
(B) Incubation of testes in collagenase/DNase solution after removal of the tunica albuginea.
(C) Transfer seminiferous tubules trapped by 40-μm cell strainer into a 15-mL tube.
(D) Elimination of dead cells by PI staining. P1 gate represents live testicular cells.
(E) Gating the main population in the P1 gate as the P2 gate.
(F) Histogram of Hoechst Blue fluorescence.
(G) Separation of spermatogenic cells using Hoechst33342 staining.
Preparation of single-cell suspension and Hoechst staining.
Remove tunica albuginea testis (membrane wrapping the testis) using forceps and place in a tube with Collagenase/DNase. Incubate the tube in a water bath at 32°C for 25 min and keep mixed by gently turning the tube upside down every 5 min.
Note: This step allows for loosening of the seminiferous tubules. Thread-like loosened seminiferous tubules become visible (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). During this time, pre-warm the tube containing Collagenase/DNase/Trypsin in the same water bath. Also, fill a 1.5-mL tube with 1.5 mL of FBS to coat the tube with FBS and place the tube on ice. This 1.5-mL tube will be used to collect cells purified using the cell sorter.
Filter the testicular tubule suspension through a 40-μm cell strainer into a tube containing Collagenase/DNase/Trypsin (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C) and transfer the remaining testicular tubules on the strainer using a small medicine spoon.
Incubate the tube containing the testicular tubule suspension in a water bath at 32°C for 25 min. In the middle of the incubation, pipet 10 times using a 10-mL pipettor.
After incubation is complete, pipet the cell suspension 10 times using a 10-mL pipettor and filter through a 40-μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 190 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant and suspend in 5 mL of ice-cold GBSS.

Centrifuge at 190 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and suspend in 5 mL of ice-cold GBSS containing 1% FBS.
Count the cells once using a cell counting tool such as hemocytometer.
Add GBSS containing 1% FBS to adjust to 5×106 cells/mL, and transfer 2 mL of the cell suspension into a 15-mL tube.
Add 5 μL of Hoechst33342 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, H3570) and mix by tapping the tube. Incubate in a water bath at 32°C for 1 h with shading from light. Invert the tubes by upside down to mix cell suspension in the middle of incubation.
Purification of germ cells.
Transfer the stained cell suspension into a 5-mL tube and place the tube on ice.
Remove FBS from the 1.5-mL tube prepared in step 5 and add 0.5 mL of DMEM containing 10% FBS. Use this tube for collecting sorted cells.
Add 10 μL of propidium iodide (PI, BD, 51-66211E) and mix by tapping the tube just before sorting.
Purify the germ cells using a cell sorter according to the previous reports.14[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14],15[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]
Cells strongly positive for PI staining are first eliminated as dead cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D, P1 gate).
The main cell population in the P1 gate is further gated in a scatter plot by FSC-A and SSC-A as the P2 gate to eliminate cell debris (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E, P2 gate).
A histogram of Hoechst Blue-H fluorescence for the P2 gate reflects cellular DNA content, and the most-intense peak (arrow in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F) reflects spermatids (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F, haploid), which should have the same fluorescence intensity by adjusting the voltage of Hoechst blue in each experiment.
Note: Under our experimental conditions, the most-intense peak is always positioned at around 65. Additional peaks at around 100 and 150–190 should represent diploid spermatogonia and tetraploid spermatocytes.

In a scatter plot of Hoechst Blue-H and Hoechst Red-H for the P2 gate, the population at the intersection of fluorescence intensity 65 of Hoechst Blue-H and Hoechst Red-H represents spermatids (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G, P3).
Diploid spermatogonia which include both differentiated and undifferentiated subtypes (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G, P4) and tetraploid meiotic cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G, P5) are assigned by the fluorescent intensity of Hoechst blue.
Critical: To optimize horizontal widths of P3, P4 and P5 gates especially just getting started of experiment, the expression of typical marker genes is examined as described below for collected cells by different gating.
Alternatives: Here, we used a Becton Dickinson BD FACS Aria II system, in which 488 nm blue laser and 616/23 band-pass filter for PI, UV laser and 450/20 band-pass filter or 670LP filter for Hoechst blue and Hoechst red, respectively, are equipped. Other cytometers are likely suitable for this application once the proper filter/laser settings for detecting Hoechst33342 have been implemented.
Note: The spermatogonia fraction will have the lowest number of cells among the recovered cell fractions. We usually use mice at the age of P100-P200 and collect 1–5× 104 spermatogonia, 2–3× 105 spermatocyte, and over 1× 106 spermatid per animal.
After cell sorting, centrifuge the 1.5-mL tube with sorted cells at 190 × g for 20 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and store the pellet at −80°C for DNA isolation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2245-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Expression of marker genes in purified spermatogenic cells

Relative expression of stage-specific germ cell marker genes in sorted spermatogenic cells as determined by RT-qPCR: Gfra1 for spermatogonia, Scp3 for spermatocytes, and Acrv1 for spermatids. SPG; spermatogonia, SPC; spermatocytes, RS; round spermatids. This figure is modified form Tando et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Values were plotted as mean ± SEM of each cell sample from six F1 mice from two mothers. Statistical analysis was performed using the Student’s t test.
Note: The purity of the cells should be confirmed by the expression of marker genes specific for each cell type in the recovered cell populations. We always aliquot and store one-fourth of the recovered cells for RNA extraction and RT-qPCR analysis for Gfra1, Scp3, and Acrv1, which are the marker genes of spermatogonia, spermatocyte, and spermatid (see Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). Primer sequences are listed in the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
RRBS library construction
Timing: 4 days
This step describes a method for detecting DNA methylation in isolated germ cells by Reduced Representation Bisulfite Sequencing (RRBS), with particular attention to promoter regions.
In our study, for E19.5 germ cells, the sorted cells were pooled until they reached more than 10,000 cells, which is a sufficient number of cells for DNA extraction, and two tools were used as two biological replicates. For spermatogonia, two biological replicates are composed of the cells from one F1 individual from different mother.
Genomic DNA isolation.
Alternatives: In Tando et al.,1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] DNA was purified by Phenol/Chloroform method described here to remove proteins and lipids. Other DNA isolation methods by using DNA purification kits may also be applicable.
Add 400 μL of Lysis buffer into a 1.5-mL tube containing a pellet of the stored frozen cells and mix by pipetting.
Incubate at 55°C in a heat block for 2–4 h. Mix the content in each tube by shaking in every 30 min.

Add 400 μL of Phenol/Chloroform (1:1) and mix vigorously for 1 min. This step is performed to isolate DNA by removing protein and other contaminants.
Centrifuge a 18,000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube, add 400 μL of Phenol/Chloroform (1:1), and mix vigorously for 1 min by shaking the tube.

Figure 5. Fragment size selection by agarose gel electrophoresis
(A) A sample tube of phenol extraction after centrifugation. In this case, middle layer is not obvious because of small number of cells.
(B) Preparation of the gel.
(C) Gel after applying samples and ladder markers mixed with loading dye.
(D) Gel after staining with ethidium bromide and cutting a 150- to 350-bp region of sample lanes.
Critical: Never suck up the middle layer which contains denatured proteins, lipids and phenol (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A). It will result in contamination of proteins and lipids, and affect the quality of the DNA.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube, add 400 μL of Chloroform, and mix vigorously for 1 min.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube, add 5 μL of PureLink RNase A (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 12091021) and incubate at 37°C for 30–60 min.
Add 5 μL of 800 U/mL Proteinase K (NEB, P8107S) and incubate at 55°C for 60 min. This step is necessary to remove RNase A from the reaction solution.
Add 400 μL of Phenol/Chloroform (1:1) and mix vigorously for 1 min. This step is necessary to remove Proteinase K from the reaction solution.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.

Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube, add 400 μL of Chloroform, and mix vigorously for 1 min.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube and fill up to 400 μL by adding TE (pH 8.0).
Add 1 μL Ethachinmate (Nippon Gene, 312-01791), 40 μL 3 M sodium acetate and 800 μL 100% ethanol. Mix and leave for 8–16 h at −20°C (or 30 min at −80°C).
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
After discarding the supernatant, add 500 μL of chilled 70% ethanol and mix gently by vortex.
Note: 70% ethanol should be freshly made otherwise the ethanol can evaporate and create a solution with > 70% ethanol content.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
After completely discarding the supernatant, air dry for 10 min (or about 1 min for 55°C heat block).
Dissolve in 10 μL of TE buffer and incubate at 55°C for 30 min.
Measure the amount of DNA with Qubit dsDNA HS kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Q32851) by manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FBID%2FTechnical-Notes%2Fqubit-1x-dsdna-assays-simplified-workflow-tech-note.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FBID%2FTechnical-Notes%2Fqubit-1x-dsdna-assays-simplified-workflow-tech-note.pdf]).
Pause point: Isolated DNA can be stored at −20°C for several months.

Fragment size selection.
Prepare 3% Nusieve 3:1 agarose (Takara, 50091) in 0.5× TBE gel with large comb, in which 20 μL of the reaction product prepared in step 11 is added with 3.3 μL of Gel Loading Dye (Purple (6×), no SDS, NEB, B7025S) (total volume 23.3 μL) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Critical: To prevent agarose from clumping, slowly add agarose while gently stirring a flask containing 0.5× TBE. Because of the high agarose concentration, bubbles are likely to appear during agarose melting, which may cause electrophoretic turbulence. In that case, bubbles should be removed by heating the agarose sufficiently.

Apply the total annealed product in step 11 and the marker in step b to the gel, and carry out electrophoresis (50 mV, 90–120 min) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).

Critical: The 50 bp ladder marker should be applied to both sides of the sample to serve as a marker when cutting out the gel in step f. The 100 bp ladder is also applied to make it easier to distinguish the 150 and 350 bp bands of the 50 bp ladder marker. Stain the gel by 1 μg/mL ethidium bromide in the clean container for 20–30 min.
Alternatives: Other types of DNA staining solutions (e.g., GelRed Nucleic Acid Stain) may be used.
Wash gel once with ddH2O.
Cut out a 150- to 350-bp region of the gel using a razor blade (change for each sample) on a transilluminator (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]D).
Transfer a piece of the cut-out gel to a 15 mL tube and weigh the gel. DNA cleanup and concentration can be performed using Qiagen MinElute Gel Extraction Kit (Qiagen, 28604) by manufacture’s instruction (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=8f6b09b2-6dcd-4b55-bb4a-255ede40ca3b&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=8f6b09b2-6dcd-4b55-bb4a-255ede40ca3b&lang=en]) with minor modifications.
Add 6× volume of Buffer QG to the gel and incubate at 15°C–25°C for 20–30 min (until gel dissolves). Shake the tubes in every 10 min.
Add an equal volume of isopropanol to the gel and mix by pipetting.
Add dissolved gel to two MinElute spin columns, centrifuge (16,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C), and discard the filtrate. Repeat this step to process all solutions prepared in step i.
Note: Because of the large volume of dissolved gel, two columns can be used to process one sample and save time.
Add 500 μL of Buffer QG to the column, centrifuge (16,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C), and discard the filtrate.
Add 750 μL of Buffer PE to the column, centrifuge (16,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C), and discard the filtrate.
Centrifuge (16,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C) and transfer the column to a 1.5-mL low-binding tube.

Note: We usually use 1.5-mL DNA LoBind tubes supplied by Eppendorf throughout this protocol, but other low-binding tubes are also applicable.
Add 10.5 μL of Buffer EB pre-warmed at 65°C to the column, allow to stand for 1 min, centrifuge (16,000 × g, 1 min), elute and combine samples from two columns to one tube.
Bisulfite conversion.
Note: This step can be performed using EZ DNA Methylation-Gold Kit (Zymo Research, D5005) following manufacturer’s instruction (https://fnkprddata.blob.core.windows.net/domestic/data/datasheet/ZYR/D5005.pdf[href=https://fnkprddata.blob.core.windows.net/domestic/data/datasheet/ZYR/D5005.pdf]) with minor modifications.
Add 900 μL of sterilized ddH2O, 300 μL of M-Dilution Buffer, and 50 μL of M-Dissolving Buffer to the tube of CT Conversion Reagent in the Kit and mix with a vortex mixer for 10 min. If the mixture does not dissolve, heat it in a heat block at 64°C to dissolve it completely.
The following reaction solutions are added in PCR tube.

Incubate in a thermal cycler.

Centrifuge (20,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C), and discard the flowthrough.
Add 100 μL of M-Wash Buffer to the column.
Centrifuge (20,000 × g, 1 min at 25°C), and discard the flowthrough.
Add 200 μL of M-Desulfonation Buffer to the column and incubate at 15°C–25°C for 15 min.
Centrifuge at maximum for 1 min and discard the flowthrough.

Transfer the column to a new 1.5-mL collection tube and centrifuge 20,000 × g for 1 min.

PCR amplification.

Combine the PCR products of the same sample in multiple 0.2 mL tubes to a 1.5-mL low-binding tube, add 144 μL of well-mixed Agentcourt AMPure XP beads (Beckman Coulter, A63880, leave at 15°C–25°C for at least 30 min), vortex, and spin down.
Incubate at 15°C–25°C for 10 min.
Set tubes on a magnetic stand and allow to stand for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant, being careful not to aspirate the beads.
Add 500 μL of 70% ethanol (freshly prepared) into tubes on the magnetic rack.
Discard the supernatant, being careful not to aspirate the beads.
Repeat the step g and h once more.
Remove the tube from the magnetic stand and dry beads in a heat block at 37°C within 5 min, until the beads turn white from gray.
Add 20 μL of Buffer EB, vortex and spin down.
Incubate at 15°C–25°C for 2 min.
Set tubes on a magnetic stand and leave for 5 min.

Collect the elution in a new 1.5-mL low-binding tube, being careful not to aspirate the beads.
Pause point: Eluted samples can be stored at −80°C for up to 1 year.
Quality check.
Check the size distribution of the library using D1000 ScreenTape (Agilent, 5067-5582) and D1000 Reagents (Agilent, 5067-5583) by using the TapeStation according to manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/ScreenTape_D1000_QG.pdf[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/ScreenTape_D1000_QG.pdf]).

Figure 6. Bioanalyzer electropherogram of the RRBS library
Upper and lower peaks indicate the internal control.
Alternatives: A bioanalyzer may be used instead of a TapeStation. If using a bioanalyzer, a high-sensitivity DNA kit should be used.
Note: A main peak length of prepared RRBS library should be 150- to 350-bp (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]). When the quality of the library is poor, the main peak is lower or invisible. If the main peak is detected over 400 bp (a problem of size selection by cutting the gel) or under 150 bp (adaptor contamination), the quality of the library is also poor.
Quantify with KAPA Library Quantification Kit (NIPPON Genetics, KK4824) by manufacturer’s instruction (https://rochesequencingstore.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/KAPA-Library-Quantification-Kit-Technical-Data-Sheet.pdf[href=https://rochesequencingstore.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/KAPA-Library-Quantification-Kit-Technical-Data-Sheet.pdf]). In this step, the library is quantified by PCR using primers specific to the library. NGS can be performed after this step. Store the library at −80°C until use.
Note: From 20 ng of genomic DNA, which corresponds to about 4,300 cells, approximately 70 nM (approximately 1,400 nmol) of RRBS library is expected. Final library concentration should be confirmed to be sufficient for your sequencing platform. In our experiment, libraries were sequenced on an HiSeq 2500 platform (Illumina) with 100 bp single-end reads using a TruSeq SR Cluster Kit v3-cBot-HS (Illumina GD-401-3001) and TruSeq SBS Kit v3-HS (Illumina FC-401-3001). However, paired-end leads are also acceptable.
The Illumina platform provides 270–300 Gb/ flow cell, and approximately one million mapped reads /sample are needed.
